comments:

MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME=/usr/lib/xulrunner-1.8.0.1

The vm crashes when the test suite reaches the browser tests.  I will attach the stack trace.

I guess we would have install an older version of mozilla for the swt browser tests from 3.2 to work on this machine.

Created an attachment (id=46650)
stack trace
Also, I reran the browswer on this machine with the I20060718-0800 build and had the same issue.
Suggest 3.2.1 as a target for this, per conversation with Steve.  But, because I am not the submitter nor a "sufficiently empowered user", I am unable to make this change.
*** Bug 131098 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

To update, though our unit tests fail, the Browser still works generally well on this platform.  The crash seems to happen as a result of disposing the browser's parent in its changed or changing callback.
*** Bug 160392 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Has a bug against xulrunner been filed so that this gets fixed eventually?

It would be good to be able to run the swt tests on SLES 10 and RHEL 5, both of which contain xulrunner 1.8.0.1.

This may be fixable in the Browser, as I've found four more mozilla interfaces that have changed as of the mozilla 1.8 stream.  There's a reasonable chance that updating these will fix this problem (a similar fix was needed for bug 155404).  I'll look into this.
Great ... can't wait.

To update, it's not an interfaces issue (though the exercise did help me find another crash that is interfaces-related).

Crashing as a result of disposing inside of a callback often indicates a bug in the event dispatcher (xulrunner).  But it's also possible that Browser shutdown is not being done fully/correctly; I'll investigate this next.
Will this be fixed in 3.2.2?  We need support for SLED 10 on that code base.
Will the fix in 3.2.x?
We don't have a fix at this time.  Grant to investigate this for 3.2.x and HEAD.

On further investigation there appears to be a binary incompatibility.  I see the tests crash when using the xulrunner that comes with SLED10, but the tests do not crash on SLED10 when I use a xulrunner (exact same version) that I compiled on RHEL4.

I'm waiting on a SLED10 CD from infra so that I can install the dev packages needed to try building swt's libraries on SLED10 instead of RHEL4, to see if this helps.
The only thing I can think of is that SLED modified xulrunner or uses different compiler options.  When we have their exact source, we'll have something to test.
Please keep me posted on the status of this.

We have been working hard on this and getting nowhere.  Odds are low we will fix this for 3.2.2 as we don't yet have a fix for HEAD.

Grant, what happens when you ldd both libraries?

ldd'ing the working and non-working libraries give the same set of referenced libraries.

I believe that xulrunner's changed linking strategy necessitates that the Browser libs be linked differently.  I found a blog yesterday by Benjamin Smedberg indicating that library lookup can go wrong otherwise (http://benjamin.smedbergs.us/blog/2006-02-22/debian-versioning-of-mozilla-libraries-harmful/).  I tried using the suggested approach and it did not help, but I'm continuing to investigate down this path.  I'll also be invoking SSQ if this is not resolved by the end of the week.

Reverting the milestone since this is not fixed in this morning's 3.2.2 build.

One difference between the case that fails (SLED) and the case that works (compiled by us) is that notification comes in directly rather than getting posted for later in the event loop.

For example, invoking nsiWebNavigation.LoadURI() results in SetStatus() getting called back right away on XULRunner SLED, while on XULRunner "compiled by us" these callbacks only come in when we call g_main_context_iteration().  When either XULRunner or the GTK widget hierachy where XULRunner lives is disposed within a callback that is called right away, we crash.  This is what the SWT JUnit test cases are doing.

Since Eclipse does not dispose of the browser control inside of SetStatus() or in other XULRunner call-in's, Eclipse does not crash.

I propose that we don't need this fixed for 3.2.x.
Our product which is based on Eclipse 3.2.2 will need this fix. Please consider fixing this problem

It sure sounds to me like you're not dealing with exactly the same source that
was  used to build SLED 10.

Is there some way you can check it?
Cory, we are pretty sure.  We tried a binary from Mozilla and compiled the same source and the binary fails but our compiled one works.
B. Chen, can you tell me where you are crashing?

Any progress on this issue?

I'm wondering if possibly a different toolchain was used to build Mozilla before it was shipped.  Maybe a different rev of gcc/g++?

Steve,

  Could you please tell me what compiler and what options you use ?
Grant has this information.
Grant, could you please share that information with us ?

The compiler options that the swt library are compiled with are (from make_linux.mak):

MOZILLACFLAGS = -O \
	-DSWT_VERSION=$(SWT_VERSION) \
	-DMOZILLA_STRICT_API=1 \
	-fno-rtti \
	-fno-exceptions \
	-Wall \
	-Wno-non-virtual-dtor \
	-fPIC \
	-I. \
	-I$(JAVA_HOME)/include \
	-I$(JAVA_HOME)/include/linux
MOZILLALIBS = -shared -Wl,--version-script=mozilla_exports -Bsymbolic

The libs get compiled on RH3 and RH4 (hence the two swt-mozilla libs, one with gcc3 in its name) as a result of a binary incompatibility between the two.  The compilers on these setups are:
RH3: gcc 3.2.3
RH4: gcc 3.4.3

It was previously thought that the .mozconfig file used to compile the xulrunner that swt's libs are linked with could be relevant, but this does not seem to be the case anymore.  swt's libs are now linked against the xulrunner sdk, so swt no longer influence these libs at all since they come pre-compiled.
Grant, does it mean that the swt libs in eclipse (3.2.2) distribution aren't correct ?
Not correct?  They have the behaviour that this report is tracking, if that's what you mean.

You claim that I have to recompile swt libs in order to swt browser tests pass.
Could you please upload these libraries.

No, the tests do not crash if one of the following are true:
1. the GRE being used at runtime is mozilla < 1.8 (so pre-xulrunner), or
2. the GRE being used at runtime is a xulrunner that has been compiled locally; to clarify the "linking" in the last paragraph of comment 28, I was referring to static linking that happens when swt's libraries are compiled, not runtime linking.

Two .mozconfigs have been used to compile xulrunners in scenario #2 above:

mk_add_options MOZ_OBJDIR=<location>
ac_add_options --disable-optimize
ac_add_options --disable-debug
ac_add_options --disable-profilelocking
ac_add_options --enable-default-toolkit=gtk2
ac_add_options --disable-freetype2
ac_add_options --disable-javaxpcom
ac_add_options --enable-application=xulrunner
mk_add_options MOZ_CO_PROJECT=xulrunner

and secondly, to match what official xulrunner builds use:
export MOZILLA_OFFICIAL=1
mk_add_options MOZILLA_OFFICIAL=1
mk_add_options MOZ_CO_PROJECT=xulrunner
mk_add_options MOZ_MAKE_FLAGS="-j8"
ac_add_options --enable-application=xulrunner
ac_add_options --enable-svg
ac_add_options --enable-canvas
mk_add_options MOZ_OBJDIR=<location>

I have compiled cvs tag FIREFOX_2_0_0_1_RELEASE and it crashs
Ubuntu 6.06 , gcc 4.0.3

--disable-debug --disable-tests --disable-javaxpcom --enable-application=xulrunner --enable-svg --enable-canvas

I unpack swt.gtk and referenced libraries are correct (from my build).
I will check with gcc-3.4, but I don't believe that it's compiler issue.
Grant, could you please send buildconfig of your xulrunner build and tag version which you compile (you can got buildconfig with URL about:buildconfig) or if you have ready build.

re: --disable-javaxpcom
That's a difference I had not considered.  I just tried a xulrunner 1.8.x built from source with javaxpcom enabled, and it crashed in the test.  So I'll build a 1.8.0.1 xulrunner with javaxpcom enabled to see whether javaxpcom or the newer xulrunner made the difference.
The tests did not crash with xulrunner 1.8.0.1 compiled with javaxpcom enabled, so --disable-javaxpcom is not relevant.

(plus --enable-javaxpcom --enable-system-cairo, latest is obligate or xulrunner will not compile) and browser tests don't crash, but I have got 2 failures.

It looks that browser only works with <= xulrunner 1.8.0.1 version.

B. Chen, can you provide more information about the crash you are seeing?  The crash does not happen in the normal use of the Browser in Eclipse.  If we cannot fix it for 3.3, perhaps we can work around it in your code but we'll need more information.
Steve N.,  B. Chen and I do not meet crash in the SLED10 with SWT3.3 GTK code.

Then this bug report does not capture the crash you were seeing because this problem still exists in 3.3.  It is very important to have a bug report that captures your failure.  That way, we know what we should be working on and we know when it's fixed.

Frankly, I'm quite angry.  We spent a lot of time (my time, Grant's time) working on this bug when we could have actually been addressing the failure you were seeing.  Who knows if it's really fixed.

There is some disconnection here. We decided to use SWT3.3 in our product after we investigated swt3.2/3.3 browser implementations on Jan.2007. And from swt3.3M5, the swt.browser has major changes and now it supports Xulrunner/Firefox library well on both SLED10 & RedHat linux. 

This bugzilla is opened and still under 3.2 stream, and is created by Kim Moir in other team,  so we think this bug report is to track the fix in swt 3.2 stream.

Sorry for any misunderstanding here!

I still have not seen any bug reports that track the crashes you were seeing from your investigation of the "swt3.2/3.3 browser implementations on Jan.2007".  If you had entered some reports (rather than focusing in this bug report, that doesn't captuer the failure) we might have been able to roll the fixes into 3.2.

We don't have a fix for this and are unlikely to have one for 3.3.  The problem happens because the browser is disposed in call-in (ie. when processing certain listeners).  If you do not have this pattern in your code, then you will not crash.  If you have this pattern, you can use Display.asyncExec() to dispose of the browser after the call-in has finished.

I don't want to mark this as WONTIFIX because it is still a problem and we might find a creative solution one day, or figure out the compiler options that make it not run in call-in or ...

Unless you have a specific case where you are crashing that we can investigate and help you with, then this bug should not stop you from shipping.

My concern about this one is that it is causing a all of the swt tests to fail and it may be masking some other underlying problems.

Is there some work-around that could be provided that disables the disposing of the browser, perhaps triggered by an environment variable setting, that would allow us to get through the swt tests?

re: comment 43

To update, I made a fix about a week ago that makes all of the browser test suites run and pass on SLED10 except for #6 (of the 10 suites).  #6 could probably be changed to not crash; while this would be hiding the original problem, it would ensure that the tests all had a chance to run.

(In reply to comment #44)

Great!

Will that be in the next milestone build?
The fix that lets all tests run and pass except for #6 is in 3.3M6.  Test #6 should be addressed before 3.3M7, hopefully with a fix rather than a test change.

re: comment #46

Thanks for the info, Grant.

I ran the entire test suite on 3.3M6 last night and am still seeing an empty resulting XML file for the swt suite.  Would you expect this behavior on M6 because #6 is failing?

I believe so.  I'm not sure how you're running the tests, here are my steps:

- retrieve org.eclipse.swt, org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.<arch> and org.eclipse.swt.tests from cvs and rename the .classpath_gtk file ( http://www.eclipse.org/swt/cvs.php )
- comment out the line in Test_BrowserSuite.methodNames() that adds Browser6
- select class AllBrowserTests, Run As -> JUnit Test

This actually runs more Browser tests than the suites, but they should all pass for you once Browser suite #6 is commented out.
Grant : could you pls attach the M7 patch (diff from M6) to this bug; and assess risk for backporting it back to M6 ?
There isn't a fix that makes suite #6 work yet.  When this is done then I'll update here.  The fix that made the other suites work is in M6 already.
To update, test #6 has been changed in HEAD to asyncExec its dispose, to ensure that it does not block the other tests from having a chance to run and pass/fail.
